climbs.name: South Face Crack
climbs.fa: Jared Spaulding & Emily Isaacs? (Unsure of the routes history) February 16, 2007

content.description: A short and somewhat silly aid route up Twin Rocks in CRNP.  Free climb choss to a thin finger crack through a roof.  Aid (or free) up crack to lower angle crack and scramble to top.  OK rock quality. A novelty more than anything else because it doesn't even qualify as a tower.  The opposite side of this crack (The North Face Crack) looks like it is  good choice and will easily go free, but it was cold and we were more into the sun than the shade.
content.protection: Several #2-4 TCU's; 2 #.75 Camalots; #s 2&3 Camalots for the anchor (or use bigger gear #6 Friend and #4 Camalot).  Descend via one simultaneous rappel off the south and north sides.  One rope will suffice if it is 60 meters.  No bolts.
content.location: From the visitor's center travel west on Hwy 24 to the pullout for twin rocks.  This pullout is on the south side of the highway and is about 1/2 mile before the park boundary.  Park at pullout and run across the road, making sure to look both ways, and hike up faint path to base of obvious splitter crack on the south face.

content.description: A nice hand crack that progressively gets steeper and then wider to a fun offwidth the top. Descent is a sketcy downclimb on chossy rock rated easy 5th class. Alternatively, you could set-up a nice rappel on the juniper up top..... bring webbing if you want to do this. No fixed anchors. Loved this route!!! Wish it were longer.
content.protection: In Camalot: #1(1), #2(2), #3(2), #4(1). #3-#6 will work well for the anchor up top if setting up a TR.
content.location: From twin rocks, walk along the ledges for about 100-200 feet until you see the nice wavy handcrack on the left. The crack faces east.

content.description:
Start up a short section of chossy rock.  Move right under overhang with thin hands and good feet. Pull through roof on gritty sandstone to  an off-width pod and then easier climbing to the top and a two bolt anchor with rap rings.

This is not actually the name of the route, but a logical descriptor so I have used it to differentiate between the other route on the formation.
content.protection: Mostly thin hand gear: #.5 - #2 Camalots  with multiple #.75.  #4 and #6 Camalots useful as well.  Two bolt anchor with Fixe rap hangers at the top.
content.location:
From the Torrey Junction of UT-24 and UT-12 drive east on UT-24 to a turn off on the right for Twin Rocks (which is on the left) at 4.8 miles.  Twin Rocks is also located about 4.8 miles west of the Capitol Reef National Park visitor center on UT-24.

Cross the road, climb to the base of the formation and skirt around the the north side.  About 5 minutes.
